eS out a throaty laugh and takes another drag on her

ight withers. She assumes a more sober attitude and exits @ drawing under her arm. g

INT. CRUELLA‘'S OFFICE 2 enormous, black and white room overlooking the city. Th s are black, the carpet, white. A desk -- half white, black ~- and white leather sofas with black cushions. Cruella is behind her desk. She looks up from the drawing with a dreamy smile on her face.
Fabulous. sits gingerly in one of the black chairs across the desk Cruella, relieved that Cruella likes her design.
Fur?
Anita's surprised by the question.
No, no. Linen.
It would be stunning in fur.
It's funny you should say that. I got the idea for the pattern from my dog. She's a Dalmatian.
How charming. (looking at the drawing) Linen? You're quite sure?
You're wearing it to the Chesterton Trials. That's in April. Fur would be inappropriate.
I suppose so. She leans back in her chair.

Isn't this marvelous? I'm taking your advice. You were a hopeless child lost in the most desperate surroundings, pleading for escape. I recognized your talent, swept you from the gutter and introduced you to a world of beauty, comfort and achievement. A few short years, and iim taking your council. I don't know who's more blessed. Me or you.
Me, of course, Cruella.
But only by a whisker. Cruella rises and crosses around the desk.
You've done wonderful work for me. Anita nods cautiously. Cruella steps around behind Anita. plants her bony hands on Anita's shoulders.
You're not very well-known despite your obvious talent.
That doesn't matter to me.
releases Anita and crosses to the window. She looks out @ square.

Your work is fresh and clean, unfettered, unpretentious. It sells. And one of these days, my competitors are going to figure out who you are and they're going to try and steal you away. I just want you to know that you're very important to me, Anita is embarrassed by the praise.
I'll top any offer you get. I want you to stay with me. Forever.
Cruella, it's never occurred to me to leave my job. For another anyway.
{turns to Anita) What do you mean, “anyway?" Cruella returns to her desk.
I don't know. If I met someone.
Marriage?
Perhaps. Someday.

More good women have been lost to marriage than to all the wars, famines, epidemics, and disasters combined. You'd be an absolute fool to throw you life away for a kiss on the neck and a wedding ring. Anita smiles politely. It's very much time to end the conversation. 10
it was nice having this time with you, Cruella. But I really should get to work. Thank you.
Thank you, darling. She exits. Cruella picks up the sketch and leans back in chair. She studies the outfit.
The polka-dot pattern.

dasper and Horace are Standing in the open back garden do Horace cowers behind Jasper.

Pongo is tethered to a bicycle rack outside of a commerci building. From inside we HEAR ELECTRONIC MUSIC AND VIDEO- SFX. Pongo is content watching the street life.
A prototype video-game, FETCH!, is playing. An animated D barks. The game starts with a red ball sailing into a dar and a voice saying -- FETCH!
Roger is seated nervously in the cluttered office of a vi ign firm. The managing director, ALLAN, a trendy young ma his mid-twenties, is sitting behind a desk. His feet are sipping a soft drink.
Normally, I'd finish the game completely then bring it to you, but...I need the money.
I'm not the one you have to convince.
He's small and pasty. The sort of kid you'd expect to be video game master. He's intently focused on the game.
Roger leans forward and in his kid-friendliest voice asks young man...
What do you think, Herbert?
flips the controller aside and turns to Roger and Allan. 13
Potentially good graphics, reasonably entertaining premise, the dog's good, the environments are engaging. Roger's excited. He looks to Allan for his reaction.
But I'm not interested in a game that has a chubby little dog catcher as the bad guy. Roger stares at him nervously.
Even girls won't like this. Sorry, mate. He gets up from his chair.
I'm late for choir practice.
What if it had a better villain? Someone you'd really hate.
It's not hatred that's important. It's a desire to annihilate. Have a nice day. He exits. Roger sighs in defeat. He looks to Allan.
He's got the best instincts in the industry. Since he was six, he's picked the top selling game every year.
Waiting patiently. Something catches his eye.

Bricks. I'm paving my garden and every time I see a discarded brick, I pick it up.
Uh, huh. How many did you find today?
Three. 20
That's what I would have guessed.
Why are you all wet?
(sarcastically) I went swimming in the pond.
The water's filthy.
And it tastes like fish.
You fell in, didn't you? No one with their wits about them swims in a dirty pond in a nice jumper and slacks. And you lost a shoe, Did you know that?

As a matter of fact, I did. I noticed it running down the gravel path. I crashed my bicycle in the pond. The only part of my body that wasn't injured was my head. But now, thanks to you, I have the complete set of bodily injuries. (offers his hand) It was nice being assaulted by you, Ms...? She shakes his hand.
My name's Anita and yours is Roger. I read your dog's identification tag.
It looks like we both have a certain fondness for Dalmatians.
And it looks like they have a certain fondness for each other.
They're sitting next to each other.

Your roving eye's caused me enough trouble today, Pongo. Let's go home.
Are you going to be alright? Perhaps you should give your doctor a ring. Rozer's had enough conversation. He and Pongo start away. looks back at Perdy
If you have a concussion, you shouldn't be alone, you know. Roger ignores her.

Roser wheels his bike around in the direction he came fro

Fools aren't born, Pongo. Pretty girls make them in their spare time. He mounts the bicycle and pedals away. He takes great car keep the leash well Clear of the bicycle.

Roger and Anita are sitting in front of the fire. Roger h ice bag on his head, a mug of tea in his hands, a blanket his shoulders. Anita is wearing one of Roger's shirts. Sh blanket around her shoulders, a tissue to her nose, a cup in her hand.
(stuffy) I've never been rescued before. It was very exciting. And you were very sweet to give me a kiss. Roger stares at her.
That wasn't a kiss. It was mouth-to- mouth resuscitation.
(embarrassed) Oh.
But it didn't work very well. You're supposed to lie flat on your back and remain still. I couldn't really do it properly with your arms around my neck.
I'm very sorry.
It's alright.
{after a pause) You give very good rescue.
Thank you. The conversation dies. Anita sips her tea and looks down.
Pongo and Perdy are sitting in front of the fire sharing blanket which is wrapped around their shoulders. 25
Anita's watching Roger. He's leaning forward, looking dow dogs. He senses Anita watching him. He looks to her.
I think we have a problem. Anita looks at the dogs again.
i think my dog's in love.
I think mine is, too. (pause) Why is that a problem?
They're going to be broken-hearted when you leave.
They look to Roger and Anita with concern.
Anita looks at Roger.
I don't think I can bear to live with a broken-hearted Dalmatian.
They're miserable when they're lonely.
(setting her teacup aside) We better think of something.
I agree. Would you like another cup of marriage?
Excuse me?
Tea. Another cup of tea?
You said marriage. 26
Marriage?
That's what you said. You meant to say tea, but it came out marriage.
I'm sorry. Do you want another cup of tea?
I do.
You do?
I will.
You will?
If you ask me. Roger nervously looks into his teacup.
Would you...?

Yes. There's a moment of nervous anticipation. They slowly nar distance between their lips. They kiss. CAMERA MOVES OFF the dogs. They're snuggling. CAMERA CONTINUES to the fire surround. Roger and Anita's clothing is ablaze. DISSOLVE

As if the ceremony was performed on their behalf. Pongo's a black silk rope collar with a silver clasp and Perdy's a white silk and lace cord collar with a silver heart ~sh clasp.

From the countryside, the city far off in the Gistance. C BELLS and the DIN OF BARKING DOGS.

A newspaper on her desk, open to the society pages and th announcement of Anita's wedding. CAMERA PUSHES IN on a ph Roger and Anita, Pongo and Perdy. CAMERA CONTINUES in on The newspaper is yanked OUT OF FRAME. Beneath it is Anita sketch of her Dalmatian-inspired outfit.
Her anger gives way to vengeful mirth. FADE DOWN.
A small, comfortably worn address. We HEAR VIDEO GAME SFX
Anita's hanging a picture on the wall of her new living r It's furnished with her things and Roger's. A staircase l a second floor. NANNY, a plump, 60-year-old housekeeper, dusting blinds.
T so loved living with your family when you were little and now to be with you again as you start a family of your own is a dream come true.
I'm not sure Roger and I are quite ready to start a family, Nanny.
That's a shame. Well, first the puppies then the babies...

Puppies?
He's working on his game. Pongo's sitting in front of the watching. Roger's controlling it from his desk.
